question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again
\textbf{before} \emph{t} hours (where \emph{t} $\geq$ 0) is given by

\begin{align*}F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}\end{align*}

(b) What is the probability that the cell will divide between 3 and 6
hours? (Leave your answer in terms of $e$.)
sols:
Again, let \emph{X} be the continuous random variable that denotes the
waiting time. Since $F'(t)\ = p(t)$ we can use the Fundamental theorem
of calculus to find the probability that the cell will divide between
\emph{3} and \emph{6} hours:

\begin{align*}
p(3 \leq X \leq 6) &= \int_3^6 p(t)\,dt \\
&= F(6)-F(3) = (1-e^{-6/12}) - (1-e^{-3/12}) \\
&= e^{-1/4} - e^{-1/2} \\
&(\approx 17.2\%)\end{align*}
hints:
If \emph{p(t)} is the probability density function of a continuous
random variable \emph{X}, then the probability that an event
$a_1 \leq X \leq a_2$ happens is given by

\begin{align*}\int_{a_1}^{a_2} p(t)\,dt.\end{align*}

How can you relate the given cumulative function \emph{F(t)} to the
probability density function \emph{p(t)}? You don't need to calculate
\emph{p(t)} here if you use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
